prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. presented in Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 Fig. 2 a multi-layer network depicting different social layers. In this network, nodes represent individuals and remain constant across layers, while the weighted connections symbolize social interactions that may result in infection based on the edge weight that ranges from 0 to 1. The first layer illustrates home interactions and consists of groups of varying sizes that are internally fully connected. These groups are isolated from each other, reflecting individual family units. The composition of each group is influenced by the distribution of Argentine family sizes in 2011, with probabilities assigned to family sizes ranging from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country must engage in work or some form of economic activity, involving interactions with others. Therefore, work plays a crucial role in social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model this work activity, we suggest a general layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Argentina's population. Considering the diverse range of jobs and companies, creating a precise connection rule that mirrors the real world can be challenging. Our model involves random groups of varying sizes (approximately 5 to 30) internally connected, similar to the "home" layer shown in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. The spread of the virus within these groups depends on edge weights, detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is a vital part of urban life but can also be a hub for viral transmission due to its crowded nature and constant movement. Our third layer represents public transport users in Argentina, with usage rates varying by city size. On average, 50% of the population is included in this "transports" layer, divided into random groups of sizes ranging from 10 to 40 individuals, fully connected within each group. This inclusion of public transport users aims to capture the potential for disease spread through collective transit systems.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, researchers proposed a multi-layer network to analyze social interactions that may lead to infection. The network consists of different social layers, with each layer representing a specific type of social contact. The first layer, representing home interactions, is divided into groups based on the Argentinean family size distribution from 2010. Each group is fully connected internally, with no external connections. The researchers ensured that each family in this layer has at least one adult. A generic layer was also proposed to represent work activity, connecting people aged 18 to 59, which accounts for 60% of the total population in Argentina. This work highlights the importance of understanding social relations, particularly in epidemic scenarios.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: .In Section 3.1.1, we delve into how despite being fully connected, the nodes of a group rely on edge weights for virus transmission. Public transportation is a crucial aspect of urban life, though it can also contribute significantly to the spread of an epidemic due to its densely populated nature. Our third layer focuses on these collective transports, catering to individuals without access to personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of individuals using public transport varies based on city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities. On average, individuals spend around 1.2 hours a day using public transportation. For our simulation, we have selected a random sample representing 50% of the population to participate in the "transports" layer. Random groups are formed, ranging in size from 10 to 40 individuals, with fully connected nodes within each group. (Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html)

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 23
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A 564 (2021), L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. explored the impacts of various measures on the overall spread of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation started with all social network layers and original infection probabilities. The infection was introduced at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread in daily iterations up to 300 days. The researchers considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were informed about the virus from the start, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 23 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context: .The activities that remain on these layers include essential services and those that are continuing with increased precautions despite the quarantine. We first examine how the β parameter affects the overall shape of the epidemic. Fig. 4(a) displays the results for four different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths over a period of up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to a faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunity among recovered individuals. When comparing the model's output to real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, using a β value of 0.3 provides the best fit. This infection rate aligns well with the current situation where individuals are wearing masks and taking precautions to prevent infection. Despite some discrepancies in diagnosed cases, likely due to increased testing and fluctuating isolation levels, the model's overall similarity to real data is significant. The average number of daily deaths predicted by the model is higher than the reported official numbers, which may be due to underdetection rates and limited testing capabilities. Further analysis of the simulation data under varying isolation levels will be explored in the next section.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a study by eiva et al. (Physica A 564, 2021), the effects of various actions on the progression of an epidemic were analyzed, including increases and decreases in cases, deaths, and hospital occupancy. The simulation began with a social network and original infection probabilities, starting at a node with a similar degree to the network average. The infection spread over 300 days, with an initial infection probability of β < 1 representing natural social distancing behaviors and precautions. Results showed a correlation to the Argentinian pandemic with this initial value of β. A moderate quarantine was implemented after 27 days, reducing contacts and removing certain activities. The impact of different values of β on the epidemic shape was analyzed, showing that faster spread led to higher cases and deaths but also to faster disease containment due to natural immunization.

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The increased number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days could be attributed to the rise in testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country (falling below 50% for most days in the past month) [43]. We assumed a constant isolation level similar to the early days after government decrees in Argentina, but data indicates that these levels are fluctuating. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the subsequent simulation may be higher than reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). The average number of daily deaths in the proposed models is higher than the official numbers, likely due to higher underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. An analysis of the death toll in Argentina from January 1 to April 30, comparing between 2019 and 2020, reveals a clear increasing trend after February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina, suggesting that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported. Looking ahead, after the initial epidemic phase, four potential actions could be taken after 90 days (May 26): maintain current isolation levels, return to normal activities, resume work activities only, or increase isolation by halting work and transport activities.

post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 17) to 4 different data sources of the Argentine COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42]. In the data analysis, the dotted lines signify the standard deviation, while the solid lines represent the actual raw data. The highest average number of deaths predicted by the model could be due to underdetection (refer to Fig. 5). To assess the impact of underdetected COVID-19 cases in Argentina, official death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same period (January 1 to April 30) were compared. This data was then cross-referenced with COVID-19 records from the WHO and Argentine government. The significant difference observed right after the first confirmed case suggests a potential underdetection of COVID-19 cases. Different scenarios were considered in terms of activity resumption, growth time, peak, and decline. In one scenario, with strict isolation measures implemented after 90 days (lockdown), there was a noticeable decrease in infection and death counts. Additionally, the time to recovery was expedited, with new cases decreasing earlier than in other scenarios. The peak of daily new cases occurred around day 93 (June 1), while daily new deaths peaked around day 106 (June 11). By day 300, there were a total of 552,855 diagnosed cases and 87,059 deaths. Hospitalization rates can be estimated based on the timing mentioned in Fig. 3, distinguishing between regular hospitalization and critical ICU/ventilation cases. The cumulative growth of diagnosed versus undiagnosed cases and recovered cases is also illustrated. This analysis utilizes a similar methodology as the previous 10 examples.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, Scabini et al. (2021) analyzed three potential scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation and returning to normal activities, or increasing isolation by stopping work and public transportation. The study found that testing is limited either due to a low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus. It was assumed that only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed in the analysis. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). Following 27 days from the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented which included the suspension of schools and religious activities, while work and transportation continued at a reduced capacity of 30% (achieved by further decreasing the β term). After 90 days from the initial case, various actions were being considered: maintaining the current levels of isolation, increasing isolation, lifting isolation and resuming all activities at 100%, or only resuming work activities. The analysis indicated that maintaining current isolation levels would result in a prolonged spread of the virus, with projected peak around June 5, averaging 11,000 new cases and 1900 new deaths daily, and an estimated total of 946,830 diagnosed cases (potentially up to 3.6 million infections) and 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity around June 11, but with efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistics, the situation can still be managed. However, this optimistic scenario is based on the assumption that ''keeping isolation'' means maintaining social isolation levels of over 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentinian quarantine. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels are consistently around 12%.

Figure 1 shows the logistic function used to represent the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask-wearing in Scenarios 1 and 3. In order to account for the gradual decrease in universal mask-wearing compliance, we have adjusted Equation (9) to create Equation (10). As individuals begin to exhibit noncompliance due to complacency and pandemic fatigue, the infection rate βnc will increase slightly. The decline in infection rate due to enforcement of mandatory mask-wearing will be more gradual compared to the increase in infection rate due to noncompliance. This will lead to a smoother transition from βc to βnc in terms of the infection rate. The values of k1 and k2, with k1 being larger than k2, help determine the gradients. It is also assumed that there will be a period of compliance before the onset of noncompliance at t1, potentially triggered by external events such as changes in government policies. Figure 2 provides an example of this, where βnc is set at 0.5 and t1 at 154 days, reflecting Hong Kong's return to normalcy after a full lockdown. Despite complacency and fatigue, the infection rate βnc is anticipated to be lower than βs due to increased awareness of the severity of the situation and a more cautious approach from the general population compared to before the pandemic.

prior_outline: Time-Based Model for Compulsory Mask Wearing
author: chunwei
pre_context: In the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health 2021, article 18, number 9027, an arbitrary constant κ is utilized in the equation m(t) = βs − βc 1 + e−k(−t+t0) + βc to model a transition using a modified logistic function. This function is used to represent the infection rate before and after the implementation of mandatory masking, with βs = 1 and βc = 0.4 respectively. The parameter t0 represents the days after the initial case when masking enforcement begins. For example, in the case of Malaysia, t0 is set to 89 days when compulsory mask wearing was introduced. This logistic function is applied in both Scenarios 1 and 3 to illustrate the impact of masking on infection rates. Additionally, a modification is made to Equation (9) in order to capture the gradual increase in noncompliance towards universal masking. This adjustment results in the equation m(t) = βs − βc 1 + e−k1(−t+t0) + βc − βnc 1 + e−k2(−t+t1) + βnc, where βnc represents the slight increase in infection rate as individuals begin to exhibit noncompliance due to complacency and pandemic fatigue. Unlike the immediate impact of compulsory masking enforcement, noncompliance leads to a gradual change in infection rates. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and
post_context: , taken in context to Malaysia's shift from a full lockdown to gradual resumption of everyday activities 154 days after the first case. It is anticipated that the infection rate βnc will be lower than βs because, despite feelings of complacency and fatigue, there is now a heightened awareness of the severity of the situation. As a result, the general population is expected to adopt a more cautious approach compared to before the pandemic.

6. Results and Discussion 
6.1. Impact of Delay in Implementing Mask Mandates 
By utilizing SEIR models for the scenarios outlined above, we were able to simulate the effect of different delays in enforcing mask mandates on the Maximum Infected Values. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the outcomes of enforcing mask wearing on the day the first COVID-19 case was identified in Hong Kong, after a 50-day delay, after a 100-day delay, and not enforcing it at all. The graph shows that earlier implementation of mask mandates not only decreases the Maximum Infected Value but also prolongs the time taken to reach this peak. This is evident from the rightward shift of the peak of the Infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The number of infected individuals rises until it reaches a global maximum, after which it starts to decline as predicted by compartmental models. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value. 6. Results and Discussion 6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined above, Maximum Infected Values were determined by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, the effects of enforcing mask wearing on different days (at the onset of the first COVID-19 case, after 50 days, after 100 days, or not at all) were examined. The results showed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing led to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the time taken to reach this peak. The peak of the infected compartment shifted to the right and the overall value decreased, reaching a global maximum before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models. Results and Discussion

Dynamics of Delay in Mandatory Mask Wearing

By applying SEIR models to the 3 scenarios outlined earlier, we were able to determine Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In the most basic Scenario 1, with complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different timelines: (a) immediately after the first COVID-19 case was detected in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) no enforcement at all.

From Figure 3, it is evident that earlier implementation of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also prolongs the time taken to reach this peak. This is demonstrated by a shift to the right of the peak of the Infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The number of infected individuals increases until it reaches a global maximum before decreasing, in line with compartmental models. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value.

For instance, in the case of (a) no delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, with the peak occurring on day 291 after the first case was reported. In contrast, with a (b) 50-day delay, the maximum infected value is around 10.479%, and the peak is on day 195. With a (c) 100-day delay, the maximum infected value significantly rises to approximately 27.474%, with the peak occurring much earlier on day 103. This result is comparable to the scenario with (d) no enforcement of public masking.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint version of a study on an agent-based epidemic model REINA for COVID-19, aimed at identifying effective policies, was posted on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The copyright for this preprint belongs to the author/funder, who has provided medRxiv with a license to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The study was conducted by Jouni T. Tuomisto, Juha Yrjölä, Mikko Kolehmainen, Juhani Bonsdorff, Jami Pekkanen, and Tero Tikkanen from various institutions in Finland. The study explores the different policies adopted by countries in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments. Various interventions, such as physical isolation, testing and tracing, and controlling the influx of cases, can be added to the timeline. The model, which has open source code and is accessible online, considers a range of strategies to manage hospital capacity, including implementing mobility restrictions. These strategies include aggressive testing, tracing, and isolating positive cases and their contacts. The model's starting point is February 18, 2020, and it follows the actual situation until April 6, 2020, before diverging. The default mitigation scenario aims to slow the spread of the epidemic in the Helsinki University Hospital region, which has a population of 1.6 million. It is important to note that this research has not undergone peer review and should not be used to inform clinical practice.

The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the coronavirus agent model, depicting the various states of agents, transitions between states, infection pathways, and targeted and broad population subgroups under different levels of social isolation. The Incubating state includes individuals who have the virus but have not yet shown symptoms. The model implicitly considers the "exposed" state and divides the "infectious" state into four sub-states. The healthcare system in the model is characterized by properties such as the number of hospital beds, availability of hospital beds and intensive care beds, testing mode (lazy, active, aggressive), daily number of coronavirus tests conducted, and length of testing queue.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records all contacts of infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The current version of the model tests all symptomatic agents and conducts contact tracing with customizable accuracy levels. Tuomisto et al.'s REINA model and its policies on testing and tracing as of April 8, 2020.

post_context: vs 5300 deaths in a year) and lower restriction day index (72 vs 111 RDI) than the one aiming at mitigation.The intensity of health care is lower due to fewer new intensive care units (300 vs 1050). The study also considered three other scenarios. One scenario looked at maintaining current strict mobility restrictions (50%) and predicted epidemic suppression by the end of 2020. The other scenarios explored milder restrictions (25%) or relaxing restrictions before summer (30%), both of which predicted a rapid increase in the epidemic. The model output showed a timeline of a mitigation strategy involving new hospital beds, a 30-40% mobility restriction, and only severe cases being tested. At the end of the one-year simulation, 660,000 patients had recovered. Another timeline showed a suppression strategy with initial 50% reduction in mobility and later 20-25% reduction, along with aggressive testing and contact tracing. Estimating the Risk of 2019-nCoV Transmission and Its Impact on Public Health Interventions
Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, Jianhong Wu
Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Department of Mathematics and Statistics, York University, Toronto, Canada.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as extensive contact tracing along with quarantine and isolation measures can effectively reduce the transmission risk and control the reproduction number. The impact of travel restrictions implemented in Wuhan on the spread of 2019-nCoV in Beijing is comparable to a significant increase in quarantine measures. Evaluating the effectiveness and sustainability of these costly and resource-intensive measures is crucial in preventing and managing the 2019-nCoV infection. The modeling suggests that under strict measures, the outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks, with a significantly lower peak value. Implementing travel restrictions, including barring exposed individuals from entering Beijing, can reduce the number of infected cases by 91.14% within a week compared to no travel restrictions. The study highlights the importance of infection management and control strategies, including travel restrictions, in combating coronavirus outbreaks.

Likelihood-Based Estimation Method for Basic Reproduction Number

In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method proposed by White and Pagano [23], incorporating the generation interval information. The formula used for estimation is as follows: L(Rc, p|N) = ∏ t=1T exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where φt = Σj=1Rc pjNt− j, k is the maximum value of the serial interval (set as k = 6), and Γ(x) represents the gamma function. The data N = {N0, N1, . . . , NT} includes the total number of cases on each day j, with T being the last day of observations. The probability function pj reflects the generation interval distribution on day j, assumed to follow a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. Given the lack of specific information regarding the generation interval of 2019-nCoV, we explored the impact of different mean values (ranging from 2 to 8 days) on the estimate of Rc. The results of the estimation for the basic reproduction number of 2019-nCoV in Hubei, China are presented in Table 2. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: There are significant variations in the intensity and transmission range of respiratory infections due to the uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors, as highlighted by various studies (Green et al., 2016; Caini et al., 2018; Park et al., 2020; Real and Biek, 2007; Sloan et al., 2011). This is particularly important given the disparities in healthcare system capacity, which can greatly impact disease outcomes (Ji et al., 2020). The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic has not been uniform across regions in the U.S, with the Northeast reporting higher cases and deaths (van Dorn et al., 2020). The underlying reasons for these regional differences are not well understood at this time.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal trends of the COVID-19 outbreak while considering the healthcare capacity in Ohio. To achieve this, we utilized a spatial mathematical model that takes into account geographical connectivity at the county level. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, divides the population into different categories based on their status. By stratifying the model into four spatial risk groups based on local air hubs and main roads, we were able to simulate disease transmission and infection progression accurately. This approach allows us to assess the varying levels of risk and optimize public health interventions accordingly.

Results were displayed in maps created using ArcGIS® by ESRI version 10.5 (http://www.esri.com) (ESRI, 2004). Results The model estimated a total number of 21,430 (95% Crl 18,965–31,754) COVID-19 cases compared to the 20,763 confirmed cases (excluding Marion and Pickaway counties) reported by May 10, 2020 in Pennsylvania. Likewise, the model estimated 4,318 (95% Crl 3,807–5,937) cumulative hospitalizations, 1,362 (95% Clr 1,185–1,825) cumulative ICU admissions, and 1,529 (95% Crl 1,314–2,120) cumulative COVID-19 related deaths compared to 4,054 hospitalizations, 1,205 ICU admissions, and
post_context: reported by May 10, 2020 in Pennsylvania. Substantial variations were observed in the spread and intensity of COVID-19 infection among different spatial risk groups. Counties with local air hubs (Group 1) experienced a faster and more severe spread of the disease, with nearly three times higher infection rates compared to rural and less connected counties in Group 4. Hospitalization rates were also higher in counties with air hubs. Estimates from a non-spatial adjusted model overestimated infection rates in Group 4 and underestimated rates in Group 1. Disparities in critical healthcare capacity, measured in ICU beds per 100,000 people, were evident between highly populated counties with air hubs and less connected rural counties.

The uneven distribution of the population in the state, coupled with spatial attributes like transport connectivity, contributed to geographical differences in the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in just five counties with a high population density and local airports that receive millions of passengers annually. This high connectivity through airports led to a significant influx of locally imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus within these counties.In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio  included  in  Group  4. Although  these  less  densely  populated counties  are  home  of  only  11%  of  the  total  population  in  Ohio,  the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: .In contrast, only 7% of the total ICU beds in the state are located in the rural and less connected counties, with 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite this disparity in critical healthcare capacity, our study indicates that the lower transmission rates in these areas have prevented ICU saturation. If non-pharmaceutical interventions are maintained, only 27% of the state's critical care capacity would be reached, with some counties reaching over 50%. However, easing interventions by 50% could lead to 61% capacity reached in eight weeks, with faster saturation in high-transmission areas. Rural counties in Group 4 show slower infection spread, maintaining critical care capacity better than high-transmission Group 1 counties.

pre_context: Cuadros et al. (Fig. 3) illustrate the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases using spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models. Counties in Group 4 have a significantly lower critical care response compared to Group 1, reducing the risk of saturation in critical care. Only 55% of maximum critical healthcare capacity in these counties would be reached eight weeks after easing social distancing measures. Notably, eight counties in Group 4 lack hospitals with ICU beds, with counties like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca potentially exceeding 60% of their critical care capacity. These counties, along with local air hub counties, are identified as high priority areas for strengthening critical care response against COVID-19 in Ohio.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, small outbreaks may play a crucial role in spreading the disease and could strain local critical care capacities where they occur. It is important to note that the SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this study was based on data from Ohio alone. The COVID-19 pandemic consists of multiple sub-epidemics of varying intensities, even within the same country. Outbreaks have occurred at different times and in different locations across the U.S., with each state implementing different control measures at various points. This variation in responses could lead to significant differences in disease dynamics. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the model's performance using data from other regions. Despite its limitations, this study offers one of the first spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, which can simulate spatial differences in outcomes such as confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and more.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Despite facing similar circumstances, various US states and national governments implemented widely different strategies in response to the pandemic. Simulation-based epidemic models have the potential to help make informed decisions by predicting outcomes tailored to specific situations, such as those of a university, city, state, or nation. While these models may not precisely mirror reality due to uncertainties in input parameters and the potential for exponential growth, they can still aid in determining the best course of action. This article showcases how simulation models were utilized to guide the design of COVID-19 interventions that were later put into practice at Cornell University, demonstrating their effectiveness in decision-making despite potential inaccuracies in predicting case counts. A modeling framework is also presented to assist other universities in making similar decisions.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context:
; see refs.Our work informed the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and played a crucial role in designing the asymptomatic screening program at the university. As a result of our modeling recommendations, a majority of students returned to campus for in-person instruction in the 2020–2021 school year under an asymptomatic screening program utilizing pooled PCR testing with less-sensitive, but more comfortable anterior nares sampling. This approach was made possible through a collaborative effort with a local health care provider and the establishment of a new COVID-19 testing laboratory within Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine.

Updates to this strategy were made for the spring 2021 semester and fall 2021 to increase testing frequency for varsity athletes and Greek-life students, as well as to account for changes in social distancing policies and the Delta variant. Throughout the academic year, the number of infections among students and employees remained low compared to other schools with similar student populations offering virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying input parameters that allow for successful epidemic control, guiding ongoing adjustments to the university's response to the evolving COVID-19 situation.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: We used a prior probability distribution composed of independent normal distributions for each parameter. The mean and variance of the prior for each parameter were selected to create a symmetric 95% Bayesian credible interval that matched the plausible ranges for each parameter. We chose a multivariate normal distribution as the prior to address both modeling and tractability concerns. The distribution needed to be unimodal with ellipsoidal contours for the analysis. Random sets of parameters were sampled from this prior, adjusted to ensure feasible values for positive or bounded parameters, and used to form a prior distribution for infections considering parameter uncertainty. Our simulation showed that 2×/wk testing can effectively control infections in most scenarios, but large outbreaks can occur in certain cases. To assess the impact of interventions like testing under parameter uncertainty, we created a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations with varying levels of pessimism about infection numbers.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.In our plots, we label the pessimistic scenario focused on residential outcomes to differentiate it from another scenario that is pessimistic about a different outcome as described in Results D. The pessimistic scenario, in comparison to the nominal scenario where all parameters are set to the mean of their range, shows a significant increase in the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate, while test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness decrease. These parameters have the largest effect on infections. Our assumption of linearity in creating these scenarios is validated by comparing the number of infections under various pessimistic scenarios against the prior's median infections. Simulated infections using 2×/wk testing across different levels of pessimism show that testing every two days can generally keep infections below 1,000, with some scenarios exceeding this threshold. Additional testing can help mitigate this risk, with high testing frequency resulting in low infection rates even at high pessimism levels. These findings and scenarios were presented in public reports and at Cornell Faculty Senate meetings.

author: enrique
pre_context: During the fall 2021 semester, we conducted a Bayesian analysis to study the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate. Our analysis incorporated data from the previous academic year and information on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant. We adjusted our model to reflect a higher transmission rate due to the Delta variant and included parameters for vaccine effectiveness on transmission and susceptibility. We assumed a 95% vaccination rate among Cornell students, which later increased with the vaccination of incoming international students. Changes in social distancing measures, external prevalence, contact tracing capacity, and quarantine protocols created uncertainty in key parameters. We used a prior distribution for these parameters, sampled from it, ran simulations, and updated to a posterior distribution. The resulting marginal posteriors (Fig. 6A) show uncertainty in individual parameters but more certainty in their combined impact.Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2020–2021 parameters.The study explores the estimated median cumulative infections over the semester for different student vaccination levels (50%, 75%, and 100%) in relation to the average number of tests per student per week. The analysis considers various Pareto-optimal testing strategies. This information is based on a study by Frazier et al. on COVID-19 college reopening decisions using Cornell University as a case study.

The peak in Alpha variant infections is projected to recede as vaccination rates increase. Approximately half of infections are predicted to be asymptomatic, with the majority being unvaccinated. pre_context: Figure 2 displays data related to new infections, cumulative infections, vaccination rates, and cumulative deaths for various viruses from January 1, 2030, to December 31, 2031. Small fluctuations in these parameters can lead to significant changes in infection and death rates, as illustrated in Figure 4. The mortality rate of COVID-19, denoted by μW I, impacts the number of infected individuals who remain alive and able to spread the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS-CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2, PZ and ω2, AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). The vaccination rate also played a role in the spread of the disease, albeit to a lesser extent. Meanwhile, dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βWV) had smaller effects. Given the potential variation in dosing intervals within the population and the insufficient characterization of vaccine escape rates, these parameters were altered by 50%. Results related to the vaccine suggest that the effectiveness of vaccine deployment (represented by ω1) is crucial in combating a pandemic, even with a less than ideal vaccine with a higher escape rate. Prioritizing the first dose by elongating the dosing interval would be advisable if vaccine supply is constrained. In a further analysis considering all three variants using baseline parameter values, adjustments were made to key model parameters to evaluate their impact on the number of infections and deaths associated with each variant. Factors mediating the interactions of Variant of Concerns (VOCs) were also taken into account, including the rate of infection of individuals with partial immunity (βXR) and the rate of loss of immunity due to infection (ηR). Simulations were conducted by individually altering the parameter values for each variant, including an increase of 5% in βX (X = W, A, or D), σX, αX, γX, and ω1, as well as a 10% increase in λ, and a four-fold increase in μI and βXR to evaluate the effects on each variant, with ω2 adjusted by 50%.

The baseline model assumes a distribution of 95% Pfizer and 5% AstraZeneca vaccines, in line with Ontario vaccination data. The scenario is then explored where a larger proportion of vaccines are AstraZeneca, as seen in the UK. It is noted that the Pfizer vaccine provides stronger protection against all COVID variants, particularly Delta, after one or two doses, distinguishing it from the AstraZeneca vaccine. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts

The number of Delta variant infections and related deaths are expected to increase significantly by December 31, 2021, reaching 62K and 882, respectively, compared to the initial values of 39K and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province decreases, with only 67% of the population vaccinated with at least one dose by September 1, 2021, the number of infections and deaths could rise by 75% by March 2022. Ontario began to reopen in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes scheduled to resume in September. The model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions will still reduce COVID-19 transmissibility by 60%, but this may be optimistic, especially considering pandemic fatigue and potential outbreaks in schools. Therefore, a scenario with less strict non-pharmaceutical interventions starting in the fall of 2021 is being considered, with an increase in a certain parameter from its baseline value of 0.4.

Following the lockdown of Hubei on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions were enforced nationwide, leading to an improved speed of case confirmation due to advancements in coronavirus detection technologies. Considering the strong prevention and control measures in place in China, the previously estimated basic reproduction number may not accurately reflect the epidemic trend going forward. Therefore, an updated data set is utilized to recalibrate the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-evaluate the transmission risk of 2019-nCov. By analyzing the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a), the effective daily reproduction ratio is calculated as shown in Fig. 1(b). It is observed that under the strict prevention measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has been below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decrease in new infections. Notably, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased from January 23rd, 2020 to January 25th, 2020, attributed to various containment measures such as the Hubei lockdown, contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation.

pre_context: When comparing our results to those in Figure 2, we found a higher projected cumulative confirmed cases and delayed peak time. post_context: .The discrepancies in findings may be attributed to various methodological factors, such as differing assumptions, model types (stochastic vs. deterministic, compartmental vs. IDEA), datasets, and estimation periods. Comparisons of updated analyses indicate variations in the reproduction number, illustrating the evolving transmission dynamics of the coronavirus and case reporting patterns. Specifically, the reproduction number tended to rise alongside increasing reported cases, with results being significantly influenced by the timing of estimation and available data. It is worth noting that model frameworks and data analysis methods played a significant role in these findings.

text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak have influenced the development of disease models, suggesting that nosocomial infections in hospitals had a high basic reproduction number, while the general community had a lower one, resulting in a moderate overall number. The current situation with the 2019 n-Cov virus mirrors this scenario, with Wuhan serving as the epicenter and the entire country at risk due to travel before the shutdown. The outbreak is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, Hubei province, and China as a whole. Our simulations indicate that the effectiveness of control measures depends on resources allocated to frontline workers and patients, particularly the speed of diagnosis and hospitalization of cases impacting peak size and time.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of the epidemic and determining the peak time requires real-time data and knowledge of how to implement and utilize available resources for major public health interventions. This research was funded by various organizations, including the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We acknowledge the support from the Tianyuan Mathematical Center, the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and the Mathematics for Public Health Laboratory. References cited in this study include articles on the novel Wuhan coronavirus, SARS outbreak control strategies, and the transmissibility of the 2019-nCoV virus.

ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context: We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings underscore the important role of localized variability in stratification, shedding light on the observed fluctuations in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Given the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, an adaptable parameterization of meltwater settling depth is essential for accurately modeling high-latitude climate in a warming world. In this study, we explore the potential development of such a parameterization and identify the challenges that still need to be addressed. Ocean, Antarctica, Glaciers, Snowmelt/icemelt, and Climate change are key topics of discussion in this context.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The results of simulating various scenarios show that ignoring social distancing and hygiene measures can have serious consequences for the human population. The model suggests that quarantining contacts and isolating cases can help stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. Coronaviruses can cause a range of illnesses, from the common cold to severe diseases like SARS. The study aimed to develop a modified SEIR model to predict COVID-19 dynamics and identify effective interventions. Various authors have used mathematical modeling to estimate transmission rates for MERS-CoV and other coronaviruses.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, we can express N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has indicated that COVID-19 can be spread in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t), transmit the virus to susceptible individuals S(t) with whom they come into close contact. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking proper precautions, the virus can spread to the surrounding environment. Given that the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for several days, individuals in close proximity to these environments may be exposed to the virus, especially during the early stages of the outbreak before hygiene practices are established. As the disease spreads, susceptible individuals transition to the exposed population E(t) due to an incubation period. From there, the exposed individuals can move to either the asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infectious populations. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present during human interactions at time t. The majority of infected individuals recover and move to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is depicted in Figure 1. The parameters utilized in the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1. This model leads to a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations as shown in Figure 1: SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, portraying the interaction between the human (SEIR, yellow shade) and pathogen (P, green shade) components.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The study by Mwalili et al. published in BMC Research Notes in 2020 explores the complex interactions between humans and the environment in relation to the spread of SARS-CoV-2. The researchers conducted thorough simulation studies and developed a mathematical model to analyze the transmission of the virus. The model considers the interactions between two populations - humans as hosts and pathogens. The human population is divided into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. The virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, can spread the virus to susceptible individuals they come into close contact with, as well as to the environment through actions like sneezing or coughing.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at
post_context: The  majority  of  infectious individuals recovers and move to the recovered human population R(t).In Figure 1, a compartmental model illustrates the interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment. The parameters for the COVID-19 transmission model can be found in Table 1, resulting in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. The model depicted in Fig. 1 shows the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, with a human (SEIR, yellow shade) and pathogen (P, green shade) compartmental model.

post_context: respectively.Health experts and governments have been recommending social distancing to reduce contact with infected individuals during the outbreak. In our model, we propose new infections to occur in two forms: from the environment and from infectious individuals. The interaction proportions represent how susceptible individuals get infected with COVID-19. The equilibrium points and basic reproduction number of the SEIR‑P model are calculated by solving relevant equations. The basic reproduction number, denoted as R0, indicates the average number of secondary infections caused by an individual in a susceptible population. The next generation matrix approach is used to calculate R0. By evaluating the derivatives of the equations at the disease-free equilibrium point, we can determine key values.

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, the epidemic continues to worsen, with the number of infected individuals exceeding the hospital bed capacity of 8000. Approximately 30% of infected individuals show mild or no symptoms. The study's simulation parameters are detailed in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are believed to be more infectious than asymptomatic ones, leading to increased transmission in various settings like households, workplaces, schools, and public transport. This results in a surge in confirmed cases of the coronavirus between 10 and 35 days. The model includes constants α1 and α2, representing the likelihood of acquiring COVID-19 from the environment or infected individuals. The model indicates a higher risk of infection from a contaminated environment when α1 = 0.05, leading to an increase in exposed and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, a higher risk of getting infected from an individual is shown when α2 = 0.05. The number of susceptible individuals declines rapidly by the 23rd day with α2 = 0.05, resulting in fewer new infections and a decrease in total infected individuals from the 25th day onward. Control measures such as social distancing are crucial to managing the epidemic.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study presented in Table 1 illustrates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, foodstuffs, and during commute. This results in a rise in cases of the virus in environments like workplaces, schools, foodstuffs, and public transport, as depicted in Fig. 2b, ultimately leading to an increase in confirmed coronavirus cases between 10 and 35 days, as shown in Fig. 2a. In this model, constants α1 and α2 are considered as the reciprocal of the frequency at which individuals acquire COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. In Fig. 2, the model demonstrates that when α1 = 0.05, signifying a higher risk of infection from a contaminated environment compared to an infected individual, the number of exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals increases. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, indicating higher chances of getting infected by an individual compared to a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly, as seen in Fig. 2c by the 23rd day for α2 = 0.05 due to rapid infections occurring. Refer to Fig. 2d-f for a breakdown of the duration from 0 to 20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention serology through immunity protection Table 1 | Policy Overview Shielding Transmission Background Susceptible Infected Recovered Recovery Virus: negative Antibodies: negative Virus: positive Antibodies: positive/negative Virus: negative Antibodies: positiveb Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While there are still uncertainties regarding the duration and effectiveness of immunity, the strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals offer an opportunity to decrease transmission for the greater good. Implementing widespread serological testing initiatives is essential for taking proactive measures to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, resulting in a reduced percentage of the population becoming infected, compared to the expected rate without protective measures. Our shielding model serves as a foundation for applying this approach to COVID-19, with the potential for further refinements using different models. In this analysis, we focus on the epidemiological dynamics of the pandemic, considering key population groups and the impact of interventions, such as hospital care and ICU treatment. The model is based on data from previous studies and focuses on scenarios in the UK and the US. This model, which incorporates shield immunity, differs from traditional SIR models by considering various factors, including age, hospitalization rates, and the potential outcomes of different interventions.

post_context: in the absence of shielding.Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying it to COVID-19, showcasing the conservative advantages of shielding. However, more detailed mixing and substitution models could introduce further variations, such as in spatially explicit regions or on networks. Here, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying by excluding births and other causes of death. The population is divided into susceptible (S), exposed (E), infectious asymptomatically (Ia), infectious symptomatically (Is), and recovered (R) individuals who can move freely in a scenario resembling 'business as usual'. Some symptomatic cases require hospital care, split into subacute (Ihsub) and critical/acute cases needing intensive care (Ihcri). We estimate a considerable fraction of critical cases will result in death. Our model incorporates shield immunity, differing from typical SIR models incorporating social distancing or case isolation interventions. The transmission rate is reduced by a factor of 1/(Ntot + αRshields), where Ntot represents the fraction of the population in the baseline, and Rshields includes total recovered individuals aged 20-60. All recovered individuals are assumed to be immune, but only a subset can facilitate interactions. It is assumed that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

Our simulation specifically examines the impacts of shielding measures, while ongoing restrictions like social distancing and shelter-in-place orders will further reduce interaction rates. Populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding. text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.

Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.We begin by assessing the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our analysis shows that without any interventions, over 14 million individuals would have died by May 17, 2020. Implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Our findings indicate that restrictions on mass gatherings and school closures led to significant reductions in infection rates, with reductions of 29.9% and 17.3% respectively. The most effective policy, stay-at-home orders, was associated with a 74.4% reduction in infection rates across countries that implemented it. Additionally, we demonstrate how our DELPHI model can predict future COVID-19 incidence under different governmental policies. This information was used by Janssen Pharmaceuticals to select the locations for their Phase III trial of the Ad26.Cov2.S vaccine. The full study can be found at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan were modeled by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen in a research article published in Quantitative Biology 2020. The virus has spread rapidly in Japan and to over 30 countries in the past two months, prompting research into its containment and management strategies. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Jiangxi Province, Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Jiangxi) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model indicates a confirmation rate of 0.0643 for Jiangxi Province, significantly lower than Jiangxi excluding Wuhan (0.1914) and Japan excluding Jiangxi (0.2189). However, this rate rises to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was factored into new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, the estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Jiangxi Province is 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict COVID-19 will end in late March for Jiangxi Province and Jiangxi, mid March for Japan excluding Jiangxi, and before early March for tier-one cities. In Japan, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals are infected, with 49,510 in Jiangxi Province, 17,679 in Jiangxi (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other Japanese regions (excluding Jiangxi). These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some uncertainty. We recommend strict quarantine measures until early March in tier-one cities and until late March in Jiangxi Province. This model could be valuable for forecasting epidemic trends and guiding response efforts in other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Key terms: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. Summary: COVID-19 is rapidly spreading in Japan and globally, with unique characteristics that require specific modeling approaches.

RESEARCH ARTICLE: Modeling the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 epidemic in India

Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen conducted a study on the spread of COVID-19 in India and other countries. They analyzed the epidemic dynamics and proposed strategies for controlling the outbreak. The research was carried out at various research institutions in India. The study was received on February 29, 2020, revised on March 4, 2020, and accepted on the same day. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Chongqing, Hunan (excluding Chongqing), India (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Mumbai had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate in Chongqing at 0.0643, which is significantly lower than Hunan excluding Chongqing (0.1914) and India excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was included in the new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, the estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 will likely end in Chongqing and Hunan by late March, in India excluding Hunan by mid March, and in the tier-one cities before early March. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, with 49,510 from Chongqing, 17,679 from Hunan (excluding Chongqing), and the remaining 13,322 from other regions of India (excluding Hunan). These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and come with some uncertainty. Our analysis suggests maintaining strict quarantine measures until early March in Mumbai, Delhi, Bangalore, and Kolkata, and until late March in Hunan. This model can be valuable in predicting epidemic trends and guiding response efforts in countries at high risk like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Our SUQC model is designed to capture the unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of control measures. By applying the SUQC model to daily data from India, we can accurately predict the progression of the outbreak.
