author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. In this study, we introduce a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, explicitly considering the effects of implemented control measures. Our results show that the SUQC model effectively characterizes the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions of Japan, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been successful in reducing the reproductive number R below 1 after January 30, 2020, in preventing the further spread of the virus.

The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context:
from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei).

The estimates in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and may contain some uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should remain in place until early March in Tokyo, Kyoto, Osaka, and Yokohama, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be utilized to forecast the epidemic trend and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has affected public health and economies worldwide. This study was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, Rodrigo C.P. Silva, and their affiliated research institutions in Brazil. The research focused on agent-based simulation, epidemic models, and the SEIR model to study the COVID-19 pandemic. This article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability starting on July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for policymakers and health authorities in strategizing their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The ongoing outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), was first detected in Wuhan, China in December 2019 [1]. The World Health Organization (WHO) categorized the outbreak as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30, 2020, and as a pandemic on March 11. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was reported on February 25, 2020, when a man in São Paulo tested positive for the virus. Since then, Brazil has been significantly impacted, with over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths as of June 26, 2020, according to official data from the Brazilian Ministry of Health. Apart from the health crisis, the coronavirus has affected various aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, society, environment, and climate. It has also disrupted global supply chains and production. The most effective strategy to combat the outbreak is the implementation of strict social distancing measures, as indicated by several studies and reviews [2-4]. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying levels of success, given the complexities of their societies, making it challenging to predict the outcome.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The uncertainties in data are accounted for by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean determined by the assumed model and the variance as determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may be dependent on the mean. However, a lack of data poses a greater concern for modelers. An important factor influencing the variability in model predictions is understanding the relationship between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical care, were tested, and confirmed to have COVID-19. The infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or not, who may or may not have sought medical attention, as well as those with confirmed cases and those who may have been misdiagnosed. Essentially, confirmed cases (data) only represent a portion of the total infected population (model predictions), akin to the tip of an iceberg above the sea surface representing a fraction of the whole iceberg. The submerged part of the iceberg symbolizes the infected individuals not captured by public health surveillance and testing, known as the hidden epidemic.The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).Why is this a challenge for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters such as transmission rate (b) by comparing model output to confirmed cases data, it is necessary to account for the total number of infectious individuals (I(t)) by applying the case-infection ratio (r) to accurately predict confirmed cases. By adjusting the ratio r, the transmission rate b can be estimated and used to determine the basic reproduction number (R0), epidemic scale, and peak time. However, the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r for COVID-19 results in a wide range of estimated transmission rates b, leading to a wide range of model predictions. This nonidentifiability issue, where multiple combinations of parameter values can fit the data well but result in significantly different predictions, poses a challenge in model calibration. The approach taken to address nonidentifiability during calibration greatly impacts the reliability of model predictions. Traditional optimization algorithms, such as nonlinear least squares, may struggle to detect or resolve the nonidentifiability issue effectively, as they aim to find a global minimum without considering the possibility of multiple global minima.

Those interested can find further information on model selection in recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Nanjing, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Nanjing, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a compartment for individuals infected but not yet infectious, called E, is included to account for the biologically realistic latency of COVID-19. This latency is due to a potential 14-day incubation period, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, when an individual is infected but not yet infectious, and the incubation period, when symptoms begin to appear. For SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms start, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. Evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the exact length of the latent period is uncertain. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but requires additional parameters, such as the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the model prediction period. The differential equations for each model are provided in the text. Data from confirmed cases is used for model calibration, meaning that deaths in the R compartment do not impact the fitting of the model. Model calibration from the data is crucial for ensuring the reliability of the model predictions in both the SEIR and SIR models.

author: chunwei
pre_context: If the number of models being considered is large or the models are not nested, different rules apply for model selection. For further information on this topic, we recommend reading recent lecture notes (Portet, 2020) for an overview of model selection. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, China, compartment I denotes the infectious population, and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment
post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we distinguish between the latent period, the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, the time from infection to clinical symptoms like fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms appear, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. With COVID-19, evidence suggests individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the exact length of the latent period is unknown. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic compared to the SIR model but introduces two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Diagrams for both models are displayed in Fig. 1, with detailed parameters in Tables 1 and 2. The assumption in both models is that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the modeling period (4 months). Using newly confirmed cases for model calibration, the death term in the R compartment does not impact our fitting. . In the SEIR model, a compartment for infected but not infectious individuals, called E, is included. This accounts for the biologically realistic latency of COVID-19, with an incubation period of up to 14 days. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infection, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to symptom onset. While SARS individuals become infectious after symptoms appear, with COVID-19 evidence suggests individuals can be infectious before symptoms. The SEIR model is more realistic but includes additional unknown parameters like the latent period and initial latent population. author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be particularly challenging when dealing with outbreaks of unknown pathogens in real time, such as the cases of SARS in 2003 and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Improving inference methods and model fitting algorithms can help to narrow down large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to achieve this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Hubei, China were based on prediction intervals generated by sampling from the posterior distribution. The parameter values and credible intervals are detailed in Table 1. The Bayesian inference was conducted using newly reported cases in Hubei, China between January 21 and February 4, 2020, during the lockdown and travel restrictions, before additional control measures were implemented. The projections provide estimates for the hypothetical epidemic in Hubei, China if further control measures had not been taken after February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) display the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our estimations, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the number of confirmed cases would likely peak at around 120,000, and the epidemic in Hubei, China would not subside until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The estimation of the duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies greatly, with durations generally increasing according to the severity of the illness. In our model, we account for this variability by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic cases, mild cases, and severe cases, as outlined in Table 1. Non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death rising with age (Table 2). In terms of transmission and viral dynamics within the host, when a susceptible person interacts with an infectious individual, the virus is transmitted with a probability denoted as β. In a population with an average of 20 daily contacts per individual, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of around 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7, although the exact values depend on factors such as population size and age structure. This value of β = 0.016, currently utilized in Covasim, was determined based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values, with weightings of 10:2:2:1, were selected to align with previous time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. The weighted mean closely approximates the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are distributed approximately 30% through households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, like physical distancing, can impact the value of β. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in different disease states, and infectiousness are considered. We model viral load variations, with a focus on two stages - early high and longer low - with the high stage lasting for 30% of infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load is determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. This parameter is consistent with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. Daily viral load affects the per-contact transmission probability (β) for individuals. Fig 2 displays viral load data for a representative sample of individuals with default parameters.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is necessary for the user to adjust this parameter to align with local epidemiological data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is considered (comprising households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β will vary based on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected to be consistent with time-use surveys and studies on infections with identifiable contact types, aiming for a weighted mean close to the default value of 0.016 for a homogeneously mixed population. In a typical unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events by contact layer is roughly: 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Differentiation in disease severity and time spent in each disease state, as well as varying individual infectiousness levels, are modeled through individual viral load variations. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Montana state and Washington. The daily viral load is used to modify the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual based on the day. Viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values are depicted in Fig 2. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced in cases where the infectious individual lacks symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted as necessary for specific modeling scenarios or contexts, acknowledging that some studies have utilized much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
